toc_entry.title: The Second Coming
toc_entry.description: Twenty-five years ago, Texans hoped Lbj would lead them into the promised land. They have the same hopes for the new president, but George Bush is making no promises.

toc_entry.title: The Bush League
toc_entry.description: In George Bush’s Cabinet, Texans are crawling out of the woodwork. Read about their pasts, their pets, their secret passions.

toc_entry.title: Forgery, Texas Style
toc_entry.description: As Texans’ pride of place rose with the price of oil, collectors scrambled for the few documents of the Texas Revolution. Suddenly there seemed to be plenty to go around. But no one thought to ask why.

toc_entry.title: A Brush With Life Photography
toc_entry.description: A gallery of nine Texans and their other selves.

toc_entry.title: Buddy Maedgen Is . . . Bugged!!
toc_entry.description: The saga of a man and his helpful insects illustrates the age-old battle between visionaries and bureaucrats.

toc_entry.title: Search And Destroy
toc_entry.description: An employee’s vandalism by computer might have gone unpunished but for a rookfe prosecutor out to test a new law.

toc_entry.title: Songs Of Innocence
toc_entry.description: In Joe Scruggs’s music Everymom evicts under-the-bed monsters, Everykid remembers on Monday morning the fifteen things he needs for school that day, and Everybody delights in Scruggs’s corny but sensitive portrayal of childhood.

toc_entry.title: Remembering the Sabbath
toc_entry.subtitle: Texana
toc_entry.description: In the fifties a Baptist minister’s daughters were expected to be models of piety —clean, demure, virginal, and impervious to the lure of secular pleasures like makeup and Tv.

toc_entry.title: The Boys Of Spring
toc_entry.subtitle: Sports
toc_entry.description: You probably think that the main reason to go to the Texas Rangers’ Florida training camp is to watch baseball. You’re probably wrong.

toc_entry.title: Days In the Country, Nights On the Town
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: New fiction takes the reader on forays into Louisiana swamps, excursions into smoke-filled Austin honky-tonks, and down life’s highway with a lady trucker.

toc_entry.title: The Roar Of the Crowd
toc_entry.description: Getting bummed out on 1988; separating church and state; facing difficult decisions.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A selective guide to amusements and events.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: Austin’s homeless find a home sweet home on the lake; Fort Worth’s impresario of white gospel puts on a no-sweat show; Dallas’ Comet crashes; and Houston’s Orange Show marks a decade of—well, orange.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: Food for thought agriculture commissioner Jim Hightower may get plowed under; Coastal tries to cut the golden parachute; calling all cars in El Paso.
